description: The Network+ certification was introduced by CompTIA in 1999 and was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) and provides users with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field of Network Administration.
descriptionMD: The _Network+ certification_ was introduced by CompTIA in 1999 and was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) and provides users with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field of Network Administration.  __This course has been CAQC'd and qualifies for CEU credits. [Click here](https://itpro.tv/comptia-partnership) to get an exam voucher discount.__
name: Network+
subtitle: Vendor-neutral Networking

episodes.description: The Network+ certification was introduced by CompTIA in 1999. It was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining the Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) to provide the learner with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field
episodes.title: Network+ Overview
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:07,629
[SOUND].

2

All right, in this segment we're
gonna talk about the new Network+

3
00:00:12,458 --> 00:00:15,746
exam from CompTIA, the N 10-006 exam.

4
00:00:15,746 --> 00:00:20,450
That's right, old five he's done,
he's gone the way of the dodo.

5

Well, he's probably still lurking around
in there, might be able to find one or

two walking around in the world.

7
00:00:25,470 --> 00:00:29,750
But we've got the new 006, so
that's what we want to start going over.

8

We want you guys to be prepared for that.

9

That's gonna be what we are going
to be doing here at ITProTV,

10

we're going to be following their exam
objectives for that specific exam.

11
00:00:38,770 --> 00:00:41,370
Because, we're gonna go ahead and
tell you right now,

12

that joker is a whole lot beefier than
its younger brother, that is for sure.

13
00:00:46,220 --> 00:00:47,505
Or older brother, should I say?

14
00:00:47,505 --> 00:00:49,960
[LAUGH] It is the newer exam.

15
00:00:49,960 --> 00:00:51,820
Don, have you had a chance
to take a look at this guy?

16
00:00:51,820 --> 00:00:52,890
>> Yeah, absolutely.

17
00:00:52,890 --> 00:00:55,700
One of the nice things about CompTIA is
that they keep their exams up to date,

18
00:00:55,700 --> 00:00:57,520
they keep them relevant
with new technologies.

19
00:00:57,520 --> 00:01:00,470
And that means that we've gotta work
hard to stay up to date ourselves,

20
00:01:00,470 --> 00:01:01,572
and that's a good thing.

21
00:01:01,572 --> 00:01:04,280
The 005 exam it actually expires of

22
00:01:04,280 --> 00:01:06,170
September of this year
if you're in the US.

23
00:01:06,170 --> 00:01:09,870
It expires in December of this
year if you're outside of the US.

24
00:01:09,870 --> 00:01:12,590
And this year is 2015 depending
on when you watch this video

25
00:01:12,590 --> 00:01:14,490
it might already be expired.

26
00:01:14,490 --> 00:01:19,090
So if you haven't taken the 005 exam yet
odds are it's time for

27
00:01:19,090 --> 00:01:22,180
you to switch over and start studying for
the new 006 objectives.

28
00:01:22,180 --> 00:01:24,590
You always want to take the current exam.

29

The exams usually last for
about three years before they expire or

30
00:01:28,200 --> 00:01:29,710
retire them and bring in the next one.

31
00:01:29,710 --> 00:01:32,140
So, this is just the next iteration and

32
00:01:32,140 --> 00:01:35,070
Daniel said there have been
a lot of changes in it.

33
00:01:35,070 --> 00:01:38,900
But before we dive into that, lets
just start off with someone who hasn't

34
00:01:38,900 --> 00:01:40,530
even heard of network clause, right.

35
00:01:40,530 --> 00:01:42,460
We're ready to jump into the upgrades.

36
00:01:42,460 --> 00:01:44,110
But what if you're brand new to this?

37
00:01:44,110 --> 00:01:46,330
And what is Network processing?

38
00:01:46,330 --> 00:01:48,700
>> Yeah.
That's actually a really great question.

39
00:01:48,700 --> 00:01:49,690
What is Network plus?

40
00:01:49,690 --> 00:01:52,940
Well, it's a obviously
a technical certification for

41
00:01:52,940 --> 00:01:55,450
anyone that wants to get
into the networking field.

42
00:01:55,450 --> 00:01:57,720
Say that's really looking good over there.

43
00:01:57,720 --> 00:01:59,660
That Network administrator job.

44
00:01:59,660 --> 00:02:01,620
I really am interested
in that kind of thing.

45
00:02:01,620 --> 00:02:05,240
Maybe you've been in as a tech in
some way, shape or form in the past,

46
00:02:05,240 --> 00:02:08,570
you really do need to have some
experience when it comes to this exam.

47
00:02:08,570 --> 00:02:13,450
But going through this exam, looking at
the study material, things like that.

48
00:02:13,450 --> 00:02:16,110
Trying to figure out what what
it is they want you to know so

49
00:02:16,110 --> 00:02:18,385
that you can pass their test.

50
00:02:18,385 --> 00:02:22,513
Or once you get that exam, it's going to
allow you to be able to start applying for

51
00:02:22,513 --> 00:02:24,459
those Network administrator jobs and

52
00:02:24,459 --> 00:02:28,041
saying I actually do have some
experience in this, but not only that,

53
00:02:28,041 --> 00:02:32,157
I have a certification that says I

54
00:02:32,157 --> 00:02:35,437
And when Don says that they keep
these things update, that's for

55

a very good reason.

56
00:02:36,287 --> 00:02:40,027
Because, as they keep updating these
things to make sure that the material that

57
00:02:40,027 --> 00:02:44,357
you're covering is relevant to the day,
right.

58
00:02:44,357 --> 00:02:47,777
We don't want to be covering

59
00:02:47,777 --> 00:02:48,867
What good would that be?

60
00:02:48,867 --> 00:02:50,297
That technology is getting older.

61
00:02:50,297 --> 00:02:52,550
It's probably retiring itself.

62
00:02:52,550 --> 00:02:54,260
So they keep you marketable.

63
00:02:54,260 --> 00:02:55,610
This is a very good thing right?

64
00:02:55,610 --> 00:03:00,040
Keeps you marketable by looking at this
network plus exam, starting to study for

65
00:03:00,040 --> 00:03:04,010
that, give it in the your old bag there on
the belt so you can pull it out and say,

66
00:03:04,010 --> 00:03:05,400
"I am net plus.

67
00:03:05,400 --> 00:03:09,380
I know about networking, I know about
networking typologies, architecture,

68
00:03:09,380 --> 00:03:13,630
you name it, I should have some sort of
experience with all that type of thing.

69
00:03:13,630 --> 00:03:17,200
And this certification
proves that is true.

70
00:03:17,200 --> 00:03:21,370
>> Yeah, and the way CompTIA presents
it is that if somebody takes and

71
00:03:21,370 --> 00:03:26,550
passes the CompTIA Network plus exam,
they have the equivalent knowledge

72
00:03:26,550 --> 00:03:29,640
of somebody who has been working
in the field for nine months.

73
00:03:29,640 --> 00:03:34,630
So if you were to get a job today, and

74
00:03:34,630 --> 00:03:38,290
You'd be exposed to a lot of things
out there in the real world and

75

when you pass the exam, you're saying

76

You might not have actually worked for
nine months.

77
00:03:43,410 --> 00:03:46,500
Maybe you haven't worked in IT at all,
you're just getting started.

78
00:03:46,500 --> 00:03:50,240
But you've been messing around with
it as a hobby, or learning, or

79
00:03:50,240 --> 00:03:54,370
you've been working help desk not
necessarily Network Engineering, right?

80
00:03:54,370 --> 00:03:55,870
So, you're trying to show that hey,

81
00:03:55,870 --> 00:03:58,930
even though I don't have that on
my resume I have that experience.

82
00:03:58,930 --> 00:04:00,260
I've learned it.
I've done it.

83
00:04:00,260 --> 00:04:01,730
So, let me get some credit for it.

84
00:04:01,730 --> 00:04:03,570
And that's what network plus is all about.

85

So, if that's what you're looking for,

86

then the Network+ certification

87

Now, if you're not looking for that, maybe

88

You're not sure if networking

you're really,

90

You just learned what
a mouse was yesterday.

Network+ is not the great
place to start on day one.

92

So instead,
you really want to start that one with A+.

93

If you're just getting started in IT,
CompTIA has the IT Fundamentals for

94
00:04:30,940 --> 00:04:32,960
somebody who just learned what a mouse is.

95

And then they've got CompTIA A+,
which is general computer knowledge.

96

Things like working on hardware and
software.

97
00:04:38,740 --> 00:04:39,730
And some networking.

98
00:04:39,730 --> 00:04:41,450
You get an introduction to networking.

99
00:04:41,450 --> 00:04:45,400
When you're ready to move up into
configuring routers, switches, firewalls,

100
00:04:45,400 --> 00:04:46,610
devices like that.

101
00:04:46,610 --> 00:04:48,729
That's where network plus comes in and

102
00:04:48,729 --> 00:04:51,497
having that general
knowledge about the concept.

103
00:04:51,497 --> 00:04:53,070
That's what Network plus covers.

104
00:04:53,070 --> 00:04:54,290
>> Yeah.
It's a really good exam,

105
00:04:54,290 --> 00:04:58,440
it's tough enough for
you that if you do pass this thing,

106
00:04:58,440 --> 00:05:01,789
then you can feel pretty proud

107
00:05:01,789 --> 00:05:02,455
It's no joke.

108
00:05:02,455 --> 00:05:06,972
I mean, maybe back when it first came
out it was a much more lower level, but

109
00:05:06,972 --> 00:05:11,924
there wasn't as nearly as much technology
and knowledge base as there is now, for

110
00:05:11,924 --> 00:05:15,630
your average network administrator
as there was back then.

111
00:05:15,630 --> 00:05:18,490
I mean today, just about any kid on a blog

112

can figure out how to configure a SOHO
router and get you up and running and

113
00:05:22,770 --> 00:05:26,530
doing that, making small home networks,
even maybe in small business networks.

114
00:05:26,530 --> 00:05:29,150
If you have that kind of
experience that's really good.

115
00:05:29,150 --> 00:05:32,940
That's gonna help you in this because
it does have that part in there.

116
00:05:32,940 --> 00:05:37,540
But with the 006 exam it moves
up a whole lot more than that,

117
00:05:37,540 --> 00:05:40,710
you're really gonna get a very wide and

118
00:05:40,710 --> 00:05:45,410
quite a deep knowledge base when
it comes to networking itself.

119
00:05:45,410 --> 00:05:49,110
Well, I say we go ahead and
take a look at the exam objectives.

120
00:05:49,110 --> 00:05:49,860
What do you think, Don?

121
00:05:49,860 --> 00:05:50,920
>> Yeah.
Let's talk about those.

122
00:05:50,920 --> 00:05:54,110
So, CompTIA takes the information
you need to know and

123
00:05:54,110 --> 00:05:56,130
they break it up into
what are called Domains.

124
00:05:56,130 --> 00:05:58,910
The Network+ exam covers
five different domains, so

125
00:05:58,910 --> 00:06:00,990
let's just kinda run
through these real quick.

126
00:06:00,990 --> 00:06:05,380
The very first one, domain 1.0,
is network architecture.

127
00:06:05,380 --> 00:06:09,510
That's talking about the overall

128
00:06:09,510 --> 00:06:12,390
There's several different topology types
that are out there, and technologies.

129
00:06:12,390 --> 00:06:14,070
There's wired and wireless.

130
00:06:14,070 --> 00:06:16,460
There's different cables and cards.

131
00:06:16,460 --> 00:06:19,850
You need to know that to build the
infrastructure up to have a network and

132
00:06:19,850 --> 00:06:21,270
that's what that first domain covers.

133
00:06:21,270 --> 00:06:25,470
It makes up 22% of the exam,
which is a pretty big chunk,

134
00:06:25,470 --> 00:06:28,510
it's almost a quarter of the exam
right out of that very first domain.

135
00:06:28,510 --> 00:06:31,330
>> Yeah if you don't understand
the interworkings and

136
00:06:31,330 --> 00:06:33,670
the different ways,
that networks are built,

137
00:06:33,670 --> 00:06:37,240
well then you are going to have a hard
time if you get out there in the field.

138
00:06:37,240 --> 00:06:39,840
And start saying well,
yeah I can build this.

139
00:06:39,840 --> 00:06:43,230
And then you're gonna be like okay,
I don't know what's going on here.

140
00:06:43,230 --> 00:06:46,540
You have to have that basic architecture,
and when we say architecture,

141
00:06:46,540 --> 00:06:49,710
it's the building blocks for your network,
that's basically what we're talking about.

142
00:06:49,710 --> 00:06:53,230
How do I build that network
out from either the ground up,

143
00:06:53,230 --> 00:06:56,700
or come in to one that has already been
built, understand what's going on, and

144
00:06:56,700 --> 00:07:00,650
then be able to assist in continuing that,
supporting that?

145
00:07:00,650 --> 00:07:02,620
And building it even further from there.

146
00:07:02,620 --> 00:07:05,780
So that's why this objective is very,
very important.

147
00:07:05,780 --> 00:07:08,480
It's one you want to spend
a lot of quality time on.

148
00:07:08,480 --> 00:07:11,410
Make sure that you understand
all the key concepts and

149
00:07:11,410 --> 00:07:13,520
different factoids that
they want you to memorize.

150
00:07:13,520 --> 00:07:15,500
God knows there's plenty of them in there.

151
00:07:15,500 --> 00:07:19,730
But, you do have to get that stuff
rock solid buried into the brain so

152
00:07:19,730 --> 00:07:22,680
that when it comes time for
either an exam objective and

153
00:07:22,680 --> 00:07:26,160
the exam itself or
when you out there in the field and

154
00:07:26,160 --> 00:07:29,290
you need to support something,
you know that stuff really well.

155
00:07:30,410 --> 00:07:34,090
>> The next objective, or
the next domain, is Network operations.

156
00:07:34,090 --> 00:07:36,950
Once you've built a network,
you've got to keep it running.

157
00:07:36,950 --> 00:07:38,510
And that's what network
operations is all about,

158
00:07:38,510 --> 00:07:41,610
the day to day operations of
keeping a network healthy.

159
00:07:41,610 --> 00:07:43,412
Monitoring if for performance,

160
00:07:43,412 --> 00:07:47,530
upgrading it when necessary,
handling security incidents as they occur,

161
00:07:47,530 --> 00:07:50,703
all of that function that is
part of a day to day operation.

162
00:07:50,703 --> 00:07:54,525
And that makes up another 20% of the exam
cuz that's a good bit of what you're gonna

163
00:07:54,525 --> 00:07:55,279
do in real life.

164
00:07:55,279 --> 00:07:59,631
>> Yeah, especially when you talked about
operations- There are plenty of things

165
00:07:59,631 --> 00:08:02,511
that you are going to get really,
really good at, and

166
00:08:02,511 --> 00:08:04,860
they're going to cover that in the exam.

167
00:08:04,860 --> 00:08:07,800
Things like, I am not getting
access to the Internet, right?

168
00:08:07,800 --> 00:08:10,990
That's gonna be a very common
thing that a network technician

169
00:08:10,990 --> 00:08:12,800
is going to get come across his desk.

170
00:08:12,800 --> 00:08:15,810
He's gonna have someone come in and say,
I can't get to this file server, or

171
00:08:15,810 --> 00:08:19,570
I can't get to our,
my VPN isn't working correctly.

172
00:08:19,570 --> 00:08:23,480
And I'm using terminology but
it's stuff that you're going to learn

173
00:08:23,480 --> 00:08:27,280
these types of things as we cover
these different exam objectives.

174
00:08:27,280 --> 00:08:27,950
That's a hard word to say, Don.

175
00:08:27,950 --> 00:08:30,019
>> [LAUGH]
>> Exam objectives.

176
00:08:30,019 --> 00:08:32,300
Say that three times fast and
you're doing really great.

177
00:08:32,300 --> 00:08:33,860
>> And you'll automatically pass the exam.

178
00:08:33,860 --> 00:08:34,410
>> That's right.

179
00:08:34,410 --> 00:08:38,350
It's a trick they don't tell you about,
a little back door on the exam there.

180
00:08:38,350 --> 00:08:39,112
The computer.

181
00:08:39,112 --> 00:08:40,336
[LAUGH]
>> Now I mentioned

182
00:08:40,336 --> 00:08:44,969
security incidents under operations, that
kinda leads us into the next objective, or

183
00:08:44,969 --> 00:08:46,925
domain, 3.0 network security.

184
00:08:46,925 --> 00:08:52,360
Security is a much bigger objective
under the new exam than it used to be.

185
00:08:52,360 --> 00:08:54,730
And that is because security is so
important.

186
00:08:54,730 --> 00:08:55,370
There are so

187
00:08:55,370 --> 00:08:59,120
many high visibility compromises
happening out there in the world.

188
00:08:59,120 --> 00:09:01,780
The targets of the world, or Adobe.

189
00:09:01,780 --> 00:09:03,380
Where these companies
that got compromised and

190
00:09:03,380 --> 00:09:06,060
lost all their customer data,
credit card data and so on.

191
00:09:06,060 --> 00:09:08,500
Well, it starts with networks.

192
00:09:08,500 --> 00:09:10,558
It's networks that facilitate
these types of attacks.

193
00:09:10,558 --> 00:09:14,410
And so we need to understand how to
implement proper network security to

194
00:09:14,410 --> 00:09:18,500
ensure that we've closed off all those
back doors that other attackers can use

195
00:09:18,500 --> 00:09:20,050
to try and gain access to our system.

196
00:09:20,050 --> 00:09:22,890
Now, security under Network+ is not like

197
00:09:22,890 --> 00:09:26,490
security under Security+ where
they really dive into it.

198
00:09:26,490 --> 00:09:27,840
Here, it's just one section.

199
00:09:27,840 --> 00:09:30,202
But it is 20% of the exam, so on the exam.

200
00:09:30,202 --> 00:09:31,386
Or 18%, sorry.

201
00:09:31,386 --> 00:09:32,479
18% of the exam.

202
00:09:32,479 --> 00:09:36,543
So almost one out of five questions on
the exam is gonna be security-related.

203
00:09:36,543 --> 00:09:39,050
That's a big chunk, you wanna make
sure you're prepared for that.

204
00:09:39,050 --> 00:09:40,804
>> Yeah, that is no joke at all.

205
00:09:40,804 --> 00:09:43,536
That tells you how much
they think of security,

206
00:09:43,536 --> 00:09:46,300
especially when it comes to networking.

207
00:09:46,300 --> 00:09:51,560
Because when you network a computer, well,
you're basically trying to allow at least

208
00:09:51,560 --> 00:09:55,100
some access to it from other networks,

209
00:09:55,100 --> 00:09:58,760
or from your own networks that
aren't physically connected maybe.

210
00:09:58,760 --> 00:10:00,430
Or I got two computers that are connected,

211
00:10:00,430 --> 00:10:03,450
you never know where a security
breach might come from.

212
00:10:03,450 --> 00:10:06,170
You gotta learn about security
breaches from the inside,

213
00:10:06,170 --> 00:10:07,390
from the external security risks.

214
00:10:07,390 --> 00:10:11,110
You're just gonna have to learn
things like encryption policies and

215
00:10:11,110 --> 00:10:16,420
how different types of appliances that
you can use to harden up your network and

216
00:10:16,420 --> 00:10:17,210
it's a really good thing.

217
00:10:17,210 --> 00:10:20,280
I mean this isn't just exam
stuff as far as I'm concerned.

218
00:10:20,280 --> 00:10:23,560
This is practical application
stuff you've got to know.

219
00:10:23,560 --> 00:10:27,460
You gotta have that down and
again why they spend or put so

220
00:10:27,460 --> 00:10:31,130
much weight on it in the exam cuz
they understand that at CompTIA.

221
00:10:31,130 --> 00:10:34,610
And they say you need to know this
pretty well and we're gonna try and

222
00:10:34,610 --> 00:10:37,100
help at compute to know that stuff.

223
00:10:37,100 --> 00:10:40,030
And the next domain is domain 4.0,
and it's troubleshooting it.

224
00:10:40,030 --> 00:10:43,218
Daniel, I don't even know why they put
this on the exam, right, because networks,

225
00:10:43,218 --> 00:10:44,790
once they're in place, they just work.

226
00:10:44,790 --> 00:10:46,032
Don't they?
>> They just work all the time.

227
00:10:46,032 --> 00:10:48,990
[LAUGH]
>> If you've worked in IT,

228
00:10:48,990 --> 00:10:51,920
you know that stuff never works
the way it's supposed to.

229
00:10:51,920 --> 00:10:56,350
You think computers are ones and zeroes,
but somehow they get 0.5's in there.

230
00:10:56,350 --> 00:10:59,520
And we end up having to troubleshoot
them to solve the problems.

231
00:10:59,520 --> 00:11:01,240
That's what domain 4.0 is all about.

232
00:11:01,240 --> 00:11:03,590
It makes up a quarter of the exam.

233
00:11:03,590 --> 00:11:06,590
It's the largest of all the domains.

234
00:11:06,590 --> 00:11:10,510
If your network is not working the way
it's supposed to, how do you fix it?

235
00:11:10,510 --> 00:11:12,490
How do you get things operating smoothly?

236
00:11:12,490 --> 00:11:15,810
This is really the highest
visibility part of your job.

237
00:11:15,810 --> 00:11:18,330
When you're a good network engineer and

238
00:11:18,330 --> 00:11:21,440
you're doing your job, people don't
even know you're there, right?

239
00:11:21,440 --> 00:11:22,530
The network just works.

240
00:11:22,530 --> 00:11:24,760
They get on the Internet,
they don't even know you exists.

241
00:11:24,760 --> 00:11:28,047
But the instant something goes wrong
all of a sudden they remember you.

242
00:11:28,047 --> 00:11:29,390
Oh, where's that network guy?

243
00:11:29,390 --> 00:11:30,840
He needs to fix this.

244
00:11:30,840 --> 00:11:32,345
And, it's very, very visible.

245
00:11:32,345 --> 00:11:35,380
So we need to understand how to
properly troubleshoot a network and

246
00:11:35,380 --> 00:11:38,640
how to resolve those issues
as quickly as possible.

247
00:11:38,640 --> 00:11:43,190
>> Yeah, the ability to logically
think through a problem and because

248
00:11:43,190 --> 00:11:47,880
you know the subject matter so well, and
the concepts that are involved with them.

249
00:11:47,880 --> 00:11:51,020
That's why you spend so
much time in these other domains, right?

250
00:11:51,020 --> 00:11:53,130
That's really building
your knowledge base so

251
00:11:53,130 --> 00:11:57,720
that when you get to troubleshooting, you
have all the conceptual data that you need

252
00:11:57,720 --> 00:11:59,990
to be able to logically think
your way through the problem.

253
00:11:59,990 --> 00:12:02,480
Not only that but
CompTIA usually does a pretty good job

254
00:12:02,480 --> 00:12:05,930
of coming up with their own formula so
that you don't have to use your own.

255
00:12:05,930 --> 00:12:09,090
You don't have to come up with some
plan to work through a system.

256
00:12:09,090 --> 00:12:10,808
They say well here's for
you, just try this.

257
00:12:10,808 --> 00:12:11,540
This is this,

258
00:12:11,540 --> 00:12:16,220
but very successful throughout many of
a technician out there in the field.

259
00:12:16,220 --> 00:12:19,510
They use this everyday and
I know I've used it plenty of times.

260
00:12:19,510 --> 00:12:22,550
It's easy to just say hold on I
don't need to reinvent the wheel.

261
00:12:22,550 --> 00:12:24,210
I mean, use what they have.

262
00:12:24,210 --> 00:12:26,980
They're gonna teach you their method for
doing that and

263
00:12:26,980 --> 00:12:29,960
it's a really good method, so
that you can logically step through that.

264
00:12:29,960 --> 00:12:33,080
I used to always say,
don't just teach me how it works,

265
00:12:33,080 --> 00:12:34,750
teach me what to do when it breaks, right?

266
00:12:34,750 --> 00:12:35,570
Cuz like Don says,

267
00:12:35,570 --> 00:12:39,060
you get the it's supposed to be ones and
zeros but every now a 0.5 gets in there.

268
00:12:39,060 --> 00:12:42,413
I used to work with a guy who would always
say, well, that's impossible, right?

269
00:12:42,413 --> 00:12:44,407
>> [LAUGH]
>> Someone would call and say,

270
00:12:44,407 --> 00:12:46,670
this is happening with my network.

271
00:12:46,670 --> 00:12:48,350
And he would go, well, that's impossible.

272
00:12:48,350 --> 00:12:49,700
It doesn't work that way.

273
00:12:49,700 --> 00:12:51,440
It's impossible for it to do that.

274
00:12:51,440 --> 00:12:52,340
Well, let me show you.

275
00:12:52,340 --> 00:12:55,705
And he'd come in and take a look and
he would go, this shouldn't happen.

276
00:12:55,705 --> 00:12:59,450
[LAUGH] And you're like, well,
I understand that it shouldn't happen, but

277
00:12:59,450 --> 00:13:01,017
it is happening, what do we do?

278
00:13:01,017 --> 00:13:02,607
Where's the breakdown occurring?

279
00:13:02,607 --> 00:13:04,628
And we need to try to figure that out, and

280
00:13:04,628 --> 00:13:09,020
that's why troubleshooting Is the most
important domain that they have.

281
00:13:09,020 --> 00:13:11,750
>> Now that last domain that we have
is the smallest of the domains.

282
00:13:11,750 --> 00:13:16,290
It's 16% of the exam, domain 5.0 which
is industry standards practices and

283
00:13:16,290 --> 00:13:17,660
network theory.

284
00:13:17,660 --> 00:13:19,450
These are things that
are very important to know.

285
00:13:19,450 --> 00:13:24,020
They're not a hands on skill, but
are more theoretical and conceptual.

286
00:13:24,020 --> 00:13:28,420
That there are ideas behind how networking
should work, ideas behind how you should

287
00:13:28,420 --> 00:13:32,550
interact with your customers and handle
service tickets and do basic practices.

288
00:13:32,550 --> 00:13:35,510
Industry standards that give
you those recommendations for

289
00:13:35,510 --> 00:13:37,220
the way to run the networks.

290
00:13:37,220 --> 00:13:39,980
Those scenarios are things
that you need to be aware of.

291
00:13:39,980 --> 00:13:40,840
You need to learn those.

292
00:13:40,840 --> 00:13:44,390
Now you might have learned those by doing,
out there in the field.

293
00:13:44,390 --> 00:13:47,016
But if you're somebody who's learning
at home, if you're just getting into

294
00:13:47,016 --> 00:13:49,709
networking, you haven't been exposed
to those corporate environments yet.

295
00:13:49,709 --> 00:13:53,086
And that's what domain 5.0 is designed
to kind of correct, to get it to

296
00:13:53,086 --> 00:13:56,852
where you do understand those things,
how systems operate inside of a business.

297
00:13:56,852 --> 00:13:59,270
So for example, a good change management.

298
00:13:59,270 --> 00:14:00,640
It's a critical skill.

299
00:14:00,640 --> 00:14:02,450
Working on a home network
when you wanna make a change,

300
00:14:02,450 --> 00:14:03,970
you just do it and that's it.

301
00:14:03,970 --> 00:14:06,890
But if you've got ten other network
engineers that you work with and

302
00:14:06,890 --> 00:14:10,510
you're supporting thousands of routers,
if somebody makes an unauthorized change,

303
00:14:10,510 --> 00:14:12,370
it can really cause some problems.

304
00:14:12,370 --> 00:14:14,730
We've gotta have structures
in place to handle that and

305
00:14:14,730 --> 00:14:16,930
that's where our final domain covers that.

306
00:14:16,930 --> 00:14:19,160
>> Yeah, I don't even know what
more to add to that, really,

307
00:14:19,160 --> 00:14:22,310
it's that basic stuff
that Don was just saying.

308
00:14:22,310 --> 00:14:26,080
Just gotta know the way things
work normally inside of a network

309
00:14:26,080 --> 00:14:27,360
as a network technician.

310
00:14:27,360 --> 00:14:29,840
You can't just go into a router and
go, you know what,

311
00:14:29,840 --> 00:14:34,080
I think I'm gonna add me a new interface
today, and plug that in, I'll just

312
00:14:34,080 --> 00:14:37,830
take this company credit card, purchase
an MPLS line and that'll be good for me.

313
00:14:37,830 --> 00:14:38,430
We need that.

314
00:14:38,430 --> 00:14:39,855
Let's just make that happen, right?

315
00:14:39,855 --> 00:14:43,380
Now, you can't just do these things
unless it's your own network, right?

316
00:14:43,380 --> 00:14:47,170
So we do need to learn,
what is the standard practices?

317
00:14:47,170 --> 00:14:49,920
How do we need to operate
as a network technician?

318
00:14:49,920 --> 00:14:51,480
What are some of
the things I need to know?

319
00:14:51,480 --> 00:14:54,910
And it's really awesome that
CompTIA puts this in the exam.

320
00:14:54,910 --> 00:14:57,010
It's kinda like with the A+ exam.

321
00:14:57,010 --> 00:14:59,890
We just went through that as well,
and they have this professionalism and

322
00:14:59,890 --> 00:15:00,710
things like that.

323
00:15:00,710 --> 00:15:05,160
Stuff that we do need to
implement as a person

324
00:15:05,160 --> 00:15:08,660
that is a technician that
helps us do our job better,

325
00:15:08,660 --> 00:15:12,740
helps other people around us that
don't necessarily know what we do.

326
00:15:12,740 --> 00:15:13,990
They just need us to do it.

327
00:15:13,990 --> 00:15:17,042
But they need to know how to work with us,
so they're not working against us.

328
00:15:17,042 --> 00:15:19,085
It does happen from time to time.

329
00:15:19,085 --> 00:15:21,730
>> All right, well,
Daniel let's start winding this one down.

330
00:15:21,730 --> 00:15:24,480
I do wanna talk a little
bit about the exam itself.

331
00:15:24,480 --> 00:15:27,520
When you watch the ITProTV content,
our goal is to

332
00:15:27,520 --> 00:15:31,410
cover all the exam objectives so
you have an idea of what each topic is.

333
00:15:31,410 --> 00:15:34,900
When you're comfortable with all of
the topics that are on the exam,

334
00:15:34,900 --> 00:15:38,530
it's time to take the exam and
get certified.

335
00:15:38,530 --> 00:15:42,500
And you do that not through us, but
through Prometric testing centers.

336
00:15:42,500 --> 00:15:44,470
There is an organization called Prometric.

337
00:15:44,470 --> 00:15:46,540
Oh, sorry, this is not through Prometric,
it's the Pearson VUE.

338
00:15:46,540 --> 00:15:48,479
Gotta get my testing center's right.

339
00:15:48,479 --> 00:15:51,463
>> Prometric's gone.
>> It's VUE, which is vue.com.

340
00:15:51,463 --> 00:15:55,737
You can go to VUE's website and
register for the CompTIA Network+ exam.

341
00:15:55,737 --> 00:15:58,988
The exam number is N10-006.

342
00:15:58,988 --> 00:16:02,436
If you go to CompTIA's website you
can find more information about that.

343
00:16:02,436 --> 00:16:07,650
There's Vue testing centers all over
the world, so you can find one near you.

344
00:16:07,650 --> 00:16:11,300
If you don't know where one is,
definitely check out CompTIA's website.

345
00:16:11,300 --> 00:16:12,880
I've got it pulled up here on my laptop.

346
00:16:12,880 --> 00:16:17,110
If you go to certification.comptia.org,
on their

347
00:16:17,110 --> 00:16:21,760
page you've got this Get Certified menu
and you can choose the Network+ exam.

348
00:16:21,760 --> 00:16:24,840
It'll take you in there and give you
some information about Network+ and

349
00:16:24,840 --> 00:16:26,230
its got the exam objectives.

350
00:16:26,230 --> 00:16:30,040
You can pull the official PDF that has all
of the exam objectives that are on there.

351
00:16:30,040 --> 00:16:32,870
It serves as a great outline to follow
while you're watching the show to make

352
00:16:32,870 --> 00:16:34,500
sure you've learned everything.

353
00:16:34,500 --> 00:16:38,370
They also have information about the exam
itself, kind of buried down here a bit.

354
00:16:38,370 --> 00:16:42,050
They've got the old information for
the 005 exam, but the new one right here,

355
00:16:42,050 --> 00:16:43,183
06, is what you want.

356
00:16:43,183 --> 00:16:45,400
It's 90 questions maximum.

357
00:16:45,400 --> 00:16:48,480
It could be less, but
90 questions is the maximum you will have.

358
00:16:48,480 --> 00:16:49,981
You have an hour and a half to do it.

359
00:16:49,981 --> 00:16:51,851
Not a ton of time, right?

360
00:16:51,851 --> 00:16:55,344
It's about a minute per question, so
you've got to stay on the ball while you

361
00:16:55,344 --> 00:16:58,472
go through and
answer all the questions on the exam.

362
00:16:58,472 --> 00:17:01,690
You gotta score a 720
out of a 1,000 to pass,

363
00:17:01,690 --> 00:17:04,820
and you can take the exam
at any Vue testing center.

364
00:17:04,820 --> 00:17:09,540
And they used to have a link in here for
finding the Vue testing center near you.

365
00:17:09,540 --> 00:17:11,060
And did they get rid of the link?

366
00:17:11,060 --> 00:17:12,260
>> I can't believe they've done that.

367
00:17:12,260 --> 00:17:13,770
>> It certainly looks like they did.

368
00:17:13,770 --> 00:17:18,334
So if you want to find that,
you can just go to vue.com, V-U-E .com.

369
00:17:18,334 --> 00:17:21,130
That'll take you to
the Pearson Vue web page.

370
00:17:21,130 --> 00:17:23,807
And from here if you go to the For
test takers,

371
00:17:23,807 --> 00:17:27,273
that's where you can go to find
a testing center near you.

372
00:17:27,273 --> 00:17:31,180
They ask you to pick your program,
so we'll just say we are CompTIA.

373
00:17:32,430 --> 00:17:35,520
And here you'll start to see information
about the CompTIA certifications and

374
00:17:35,520 --> 00:17:36,330
exams.

375
00:17:36,330 --> 00:17:38,880
And from here we can find
a testing center that's near you.

376
00:17:38,880 --> 00:17:42,121
So if I come in and
punch in a test center near me,

377
00:17:42,121 --> 00:17:46,510
I'll just say zip code 32605,
and I'll search for that.

378
00:17:46,510 --> 00:17:49,320
And it'll give me a list of the various
testing centers that are available.

379
00:17:49,320 --> 00:17:52,371
I can go to the University of Florida or
Bradford Union Technical Center.

380
00:17:52,371 --> 00:17:53,347
I don't actually know where that is.

381
00:17:53,347 --> 00:17:56,370
But you can pick any of these places and
go and take it.

382
00:17:56,370 --> 00:17:57,710
You'll find there's
plenty of them near you.

383
00:17:57,710 --> 00:18:02,030
And I'm in the US, but
Pearson Vue is all over the world.

384
00:18:02,030 --> 00:18:03,810
Let's say I'm in Berlin, Germany.

385
00:18:05,310 --> 00:18:08,680
If I punch in Berlin
we'll see what we get.

386
00:18:08,680 --> 00:18:11,540
Looks like we got several
right there in Germany.

387
00:18:11,540 --> 00:18:12,954
So you can find one definitely near you.

388
00:18:12,954 --> 00:18:14,695
The exam cost,
do you remember that Daniel?

389
00:18:14,695 --> 00:18:21,100
>> Yes, we were looking at it and it's
$277 US if you're in the United States.

390
00:18:21,100 --> 00:18:24,030
I don't know what that equals
in British pounds or euros or

391
00:18:24,030 --> 00:18:26,140
whatever the case may be, but
you can do the conversion.

392
00:18:26,140 --> 00:18:27,070
It's quite simple.

393
00:18:27,070 --> 00:18:29,360
Google does a lot of cool things for us.

394
00:18:29,360 --> 00:18:34,320
But in the US if I wanted to take to exam
today I would have to pay 277 bones.

395
00:18:34,320 --> 00:18:38,620
That's a good price, but
I get a lot with that.

396
00:18:38,620 --> 00:18:41,910
If I get that certification,
that is an investment.

397
00:18:41,910 --> 00:18:45,390
It is a really good investment
into my future and my career,

398
00:18:45,390 --> 00:18:48,650
and it's going to lead to me
making more money myself.

399
00:18:48,650 --> 00:18:53,900
So that $277 is really a paltry sum, a
drop in the bucket when it comes to this.

400
00:18:53,900 --> 00:18:56,050
Now, that being said, I don't want
you to go out there and think,

401
00:18:56,050 --> 00:18:59,510
oh, I'll just study a little book,
maybe watch a couple of ITProTV videos and

402
00:18:59,510 --> 00:19:01,550
I'm gonna go smoke this exam.

403
00:19:01,550 --> 00:19:02,400
Take your time.

404
00:19:02,400 --> 00:19:04,750
Really take this exam seriously.

405
00:19:04,750 --> 00:19:08,564
It is a tougher exam
than what it would be.

406
00:19:08,564 --> 00:19:12,380
They've really upped their game,
so I want you guys to be prepared.

407
00:19:12,380 --> 00:19:13,270
Use our videos.

408
00:19:13,270 --> 00:19:15,299
Use any other type of study
material that you can find.

409
00:19:15,299 --> 00:19:19,730
There are great books and websites that
are just littered all over the Internet.

410
00:19:19,730 --> 00:19:22,250
You can find all sorts of great
information that's gonna help

411
00:19:22,250 --> 00:19:23,490
you get this done.

412
00:19:23,490 --> 00:19:26,530
Really know that information so that when
you sit down at that testing center,

413
00:19:26,530 --> 00:19:31,440
and you've got that exam in front of you,
it's just cranking it out no problem.

414
00:19:31,440 --> 00:19:32,930
It's very simple.

415
00:19:32,930 --> 00:19:36,280
Now again, 90 questions with 90 minutes.

416
00:19:36,280 --> 00:19:36,887
Is that enough time, Don?

417
00:19:36,887 --> 00:19:37,711
Can you get it done?

418
00:19:37,711 --> 00:19:40,550
>> Absolutely,
people pass it every single day.

419
00:19:40,550 --> 00:19:42,395
We've both done it multiple times.

420
00:19:42,395 --> 00:19:45,060
[LAUGH] So it's a very doable goal.

421
00:19:45,060 --> 00:19:46,009
You just have to hit the books.

422
00:19:46,009 --> 00:19:46,567
>> Yeah.

423
00:19:46,567 --> 00:19:49,837
>> All right, well, if all of that
sounds interesting and exciting to you,

424
00:19:49,837 --> 00:19:51,280
then you are in the right place.

425
00:19:51,280 --> 00:19:51,850
Stay tuned.

426
00:19:51,850 --> 00:19:54,140
We've got Network+ episodes coming up.

427
00:19:54,140 --> 00:19:55,590
If that doesn't sound quite right for
you or

428
00:19:55,590 --> 00:19:58,530
if you're not quite ready to jump
right into Network+, remember,

429
00:19:58,530 --> 00:20:02,630
with your ITProTV subscription you
have access to our entire catalog.

430
00:20:02,630 --> 00:20:07,170
CompTIA IT Fundamentals and
A+ are both great places to get started.

431
00:20:07,170 --> 00:20:10,407
For other networking knowledge we
have things like the Cisco CCNA or

432
00:20:10,407 --> 00:20:13,834
Cisco CCNT you can jump into,
a little more focused on the Cisco world.

433
00:20:13,834 --> 00:20:16,388
There's a lot of different
resources available on the site.

434
00:20:16,388 --> 00:20:17,851
Make sure you take advantage of them.

435
00:20:17,851 --> 00:20:21,426
But if Network+ is what you want,
stay tuned cuz it's coming up next.

436
00:20:21,426 --> 00:20:26,690
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel take you through some of the various network devices that you will most likely encounter as a network tech in the field. They explain in great detail network appliances like routers, switches, firewalls, and even intrusion detection/prevention systems.
episodes.title: Various Network Devices

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue on with familiarizing you with various network devices. Here they cover network appliances like content filters, load balancers, and VPN concentrators.
episodes.title: Various Network Devices Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel describe and demonstrate some of the networking services and applications that a Network+ certified tech will need to support. In great detail, they explain and even show you the "science" behind Virtual Private Networks (VPN) from learning what a VPN is, to the various types of VPNs and their associated encryption types and tunnels.
episodes.title: Networking Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue exploring different networking services and applications; specifically diving into remote authentication, authorization, and accounting servers (TACACS/RADIUS), Remote Access Servers (RAS), VoIP, and more.
episodes.title: Networking Services Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to install and configure some of the various networking services/applications that are found on a typical network. Topics covered in no small detail include DHCP and DNS; two of the major services found on most networks.
episodes.title: Networking Services/Applications

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie pick back up the task of explaining how to install and configure various networking services/applications. This time they are covering Proxy servers and their various applications. Also covered is Network Address Translation (NAT) and Port Forwarding.
episodes.title: Networking Services/Applications Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie examine the different network topologies and types covered in the Net+ exam. They cover all the bases starting with Mesh topologies and working all the way through Bus, Ring, Star, and Hybrid. Also covered are network types like Point-to-Point and Client/Server.
episodes.title: Common Network Topologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the different network infrastructures and how they are implemented. Common implementations like WAN, MAN, and LAN are covered as well as some more specialized networks like Industrial Control Systems (ICS) and Medianets.
episodes.title: Network Infrastructures

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue exploring the different routing protocols as well as covering the myriad of routing metrics used to calculate route paths. Also, they show you how to increase the availability of a network by employing redundancy protocols like Virtual Routing Redundancy Protocol (VRRP) and Hot Standby Routing Protocol (HSRP)
episodes.title: Basic Routing Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel explain the basics of Unified Communication (UC) technologies like Voice over IP phone systems, video conferencing, and other real-time services. They also give you an overview of the UC servers, end devices, and gateways that facilitate the various UC services.
episodes.title: Communication Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore and contrast the technologies that support virtualization and cloud services. They go over the different virtualized network hardware like virtual routers, switches, and NICs as well as covering the topic of storage over a network. Cloud services like IaaS, SaaS, and PaaS are also discussed.
episodes.title: Cloud and Virtualization

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take you through all the considerations to take into account when designing and building a basic network. They explain some of the advantages as well as the disadvantages when it comes to both wired and wireless network, while also showing you some of the devices needed to implement either.
episodes.title: Building a Basic Network

episodes.description: In this episode Don begins the multipart series on IPv4 subnetting. He begins with a detailed discussion on what a subnet is, what it does and what we use it for. He continues with explaining the process of decimal to binary conversion and how to determine whether an IP address is part of the same network as another address.
episodes.title: IPv4 Subnetting

episodes.description: In this episode Don continues with a discussion on IPv4 subnetting with leveraging the use of subnets to create smaller or larger network to optimize network performance. He uses examples of splitting and combining networks to ensure enough IP address are available for network devices.
episodes.title: IPv4 Subnetting Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Don describes the characteristics of IP addressing. He begins with breaking down the IP address to binary conversion and how the subnet mask comes into play in determining which class the IP address belongs to. He wraps the show with a discussion on the main classes of IP addresses; both public and private classes.
episodes.title: IP Addressing

episodes.description: In this episode Don covers the characteristics of IPv6 addressing. He begins by comparing IPv6 to IPv4 address and how they differ. He discusses the various classes of IPv6 addresses such as the private, loopback, multicast and link-local addresses.
episodes.title: IPv6 Addressing

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue walking you through different types of monitoring and monitoring tools. They show you how to use monitors like Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) for collecting security logs from multiple points; and then show how to do some wireless monitoring for getting the most efficient wireless network setup. Also covered is environmental and power monitoring.
episodes.title: Monitoring Tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue walking you through different types of monitoring and monitoring tools. They show you how to use monitors like Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) for collecting security logs from multiple points; and then show how to do some wireless monitoring for getting the most efficient wireless network setup. Also covered is environmental and power monitoring.
episodes.title: Monitoring Tools Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain how to analyze the info and reports gathered by your monitoring and performance tools. They explain some of the basic concepts like baselines and bottlenecks and then get into more detailed concepts like interface monitoring output, graphs, and utilization charts.
episodes.title: Analyzing Metrics and Reports

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to implement certain resources to support and manage your network and/or system configurations. They describe the importance of having good backups and network documentation, the basics of Network Access Control systems, asset management, and network diagrams.
episodes.title: Support Config Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the importance of network segmentation. They explain the logic behind the need to segregate networks and give examples of the types of systems that might need segmenting like SCADA, test environments, and legacy systems.
episodes.title: Network Segmentation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the importance and procedure for installing and applying various types of patches and updates. They talk about vulnerability patches, driver updates, and firmware updates. They also explain why you might need to downgrade an updated system and the difference between the two.
episodes.title: Patches and Updates

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain the functions of a network switch as well as its features and configuration. They show you how to create things like VLANs, set a default gateway and configure IP addresses. They also explain features like Power-over-Ethernet(PoE) and VLAN-Trunking-Protocol (VTP) and how they can benefit your network.
episodes.title: Configuring Switches

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue explaining switch configuration. They expound on switch management by discussing user authentication; both locally and server based (AAA). They also instruct you on how to connect to a managed switch via a console cable or through remote protocols like telnet.
episodes.title: Configuring Switches Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss implementing wireless infrastructure and the technologies that support it. They explain the different wireless devices like Access Points and the various mobile devices. Then they discuss topics like placement, antennae types, and wireless topologies.
episodes.title: Wireless Infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie go over the basic concepts that pertain to risk management and disaster recovery. They explore the standards, policies, and procedures that will help ensure business continuity in the event of a worst-case scenario. Topics covered include disaster recovery, data breaches, end-user awareness and training, and risk mitigation through vulnerability testing and redundancy.
episodes.title: Risk Related Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the various techniques used when implementing network hardening. They cover security techniques such as antivirus/antimalware for the workstation and the network wire. They also demonstrate switch port security that helps in maintaining data and workstation integrity. Also discussed is the importance of using secure protocols like SSH, SSL, and IPsec.
episodes.title: Network Hardening Techniques

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue explaining the various techniques used when implementing network hardening. They cover the use of Access Control Lists (ACL) and web proxies to filter content, wireless security, and user authentication techniques like PAP, CHAP, and Kerberos. Hashing to maintain integrity is also covered.
episodes.title: Network Hardening Techniques Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain and contrast the various physical controls that can be implemented for security. They discuss physical security measures like Mantraps, video surveillance systems, biometrics, and electronic lock systems.
episodes.title: Physical Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie go over the basic concepts of digital forensics. They introduce you to the standard practices and procedures for handling an incident be it accidental or criminal. They cover concepts like eDiscovery, documentation, chain of custody, and data transport.
episodes.title: Basic Forensic Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the basics of installing and configuring a firewall. They explain the differences between the types of firewalls, whether they be software or hardware, the type of firewall service they can provide, as well as some practical use and implementation.
episodes.title: Basic Firewall Config

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain the how, when, and where of implementing Network Access Control (NAC) systems. They give an overview of NAC operations for granting and denying access to networks and network resources and then describe the different NAC models like Mandatory, Discretionary, Role and Rule based.
episodes.title: Access Control Models

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie walk you through the CompTIA network troubleshooting method. Step-by-step they explore and explain each process; from identifying the problem, to implementing a solution and documenting your findings.
episodes.title: Net+ Troubleshooting Theory

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss troubleshooting and resolving common wireless issues. They explain various issues like signal loss, interference, overlapping channels, and channel saturation.
episodes.title: Common Wireless Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie walk you through common issues with copper cable media. They discuss troubleshooting problems like electrical shorts and cuts, incorrect termination, and interference from other electrical devices.
episodes.title: Copper Cable Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss troubleshooting, and resolving common issue with fiber optic cables. They cover issues like signal attenuation, wavelength mismatches, and bend radius limitations.
episodes.title: Common Fiber Optics Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike walk you through many common security issues and what you can do to troubleshoot and resolve them. They discuss security problems like misconfigured firewalls, denial of service attacks, malicious users, and authentication issues.
episodes.title: Resolving Security Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain how to troubleshoot and resolve common WAN issues. They describe the different types of equipment involved with connecting WANs along with techniques for resolving problems with that equipment when they arise. Also discussed is router interface errors and misconfiguration issue as well as DNS and even satellite WAN issues.
episodes.title: Common WAN Issues

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Ronnie take a look at some of easily overlooked network issues that can cause networking performance issues.  They show and discuss not only issues that directly relate to the end user but also at the network service level and network infrastructure.
episodes.title: Common Network Issues

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike describe the layers of the OSI reference model. They walk you through each layer describing its purpose and how it is used when sending and receiving data over a computer network.
episodes.title: OSI Layers

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe many of the basic networking theories and concepts you might encounter as a network technician. Topics covered include data encapsulation, signal modulation/multiplexing, and data collision detection and avoidance.
episodes.title: Basic Network Theory

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie take a look a different scenarios that IT professionals must consider implementing policies and procedures. They show some of the different templates available and discuss why they are needed.
episodes.title: Policies and Procedures

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie take a look into some of the most common safety practices around high voltage, equipment installation, chemical spills and emergencies.  They also describe fire supression systems including Clean Agent.
episodes.title: Safety Practices

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie talk about equipment installation considerations including basic scability in design to practical installation matters like power, placement and monitoring systems to be considered. They show example from the ITProTV facilities.
episodes.title: Managing Equipment

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Ronnie discuss the needs and procedures of basic change management.  They talk about the importance of documentation and communication that should be part of every IT team when equipment changes, configuration changes and event changes can impact the network.
episodes.title: Change Management

topics.title: Industry standards, practices, and network theory

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel explore a few miscellaneous topics pertaining to wired and wireless technologies. Here they cover media converters like Single-Mode Fiber to Ethernet, Multimode Fiber to Ethernet, Fiber to Coax, and Single Mode to Multimode Fiber.
episodes.title: Additional Information

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel look at a few more miscellaneous topics; this time looking at IPv6 related content. Here they cover DHCP6, which is automatic addressing of nodes using the IPv6 networking protocol. They explain stateless, stateful, and manual configurations. They also cover IPv6 in a still largely IPv4 world and how the two can coexist with 6to4/4to6 tunneling and Teredo/Miredo.
episodes.title: Additional Information Part 2
